docs.title: Skill Registry (skr)
docs.text: skr is a tool designed to manage Agent Skills—a lightweight, open format for extending AI agent capabilities with specialized knowledge and workflows.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text:
The primary goal of skr is to enable the pushing, pulling, and maintenance of Agent Skills using OCI (Open Container Initiative) Image registries, similar to the workflow used for container images on platforms like GitHub or Docker Hub.

This allows for a standardized, versioned, and distributed ecosystem for sharing AI capabilities.

docs.title: Basic Commands
docs.text:
# Build a skill from the current directory
skr build . -t my-registry.com/my-skill:v1.0.0

# Push a skill to a registry
skr push my-registry.com/my-skill:v1.0.0

# Install a skill
skr install my-registry.com/my-skill:v1.0.0

# Remove an installed skill
skr rm my-registry.com/my-skill

# Inspect a remote skill
skr inspect my-registry.com/my-skill:v1.0.0

docs.title: Registry Authentication
docs.text:
# Log in to a registry
skr registry login my-registry.com --username <user> --password <token>

# Log out
skr registry logout my-registry.com

docs.title: Further Reading
docs.text:
1. anthropic/skills
  2. Codex Skills
  3. Antigravity Skills
  4. Agent Skills

docs.title: Agent Skill
docs.text:
An Agent Skill is a packaged unit of capability for an AI Agent. It is defined by a SKILL.md and may contain supporting files (scripts, prompts, schemas).

skr treats skills like container images. They are: - Versioned: Using tags (e.g., v1.0.0, latest). - Portable: Can be pushed to standard OCI registries. - Layered: Deduplicated storage of content.

docs.title: OCI Store
docs.text:
skr uses the Open Container Initiative (OCI) specifications for storage and distribution. - Manifest: Describes the skill content (config + layers). - Config: Metadata about the skill (creation time, author, etc.). - Layers: The actual file content (tar.gz).

This compatibility allows skr to work with existing infrastructure like GitHub Packages (ghcr.io), Docker Hub, Harbor, etc.

docs.title: The Global vs. Local Scope
docs.text:
• System Store: A global cache of all downloaded/built artifacts on your machine.
  • Project Scope: When you run skr install, skills are "installed" into your project (referenced in .skr.yaml and synced to .agent/skills).

docs.title: How-to: Manage Registry Interactions
docs.text: skr allows you to push and pull Agent Skills from OCI registries like GitHub Packages, Docker Hub, or bespoke OCI registries.

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
Before interacting with a private registry, you must log in.

skr registry login ghcr.io --username <your-username>

You will be prompted for a password (or PAT for GitHub). Credentials are stored securely in your system keyring.

docs.title: Using Stdin for CI/CD
docs.text:
For automated environments, you can pipe the password:

echo $CR_PAT | skr registry login ghcr.io -u <user> --password-stdin

docs.title: Pushing a Skill
docs.text:
Once built, you can push a skill to a registry.

  1. Build with the full registry tag:

    skr build ./my-skill --tag ghcr.io/myuser/my-skill:v1

    Note: skr build automatically detects your git remote and adds it as a source annotation for GitHub Packages.

  2. Push:

    skr push ghcr.io/myuser/my-skill:v1

docs.title: Pulling a Skill
docs.text:
You can download a skill without installing it (useful for inspection):

skr pull ghcr.io/myuser/my-skill:v1

To install directly (which also pulls if needed):

skr install ghcr.io/myuser/my-skill:v1

docs.title: How-to: Manage Local System
docs.text: skr maintains a local OCI-compliant store at ~/.local/share/skr/store (Linux) or equivalent XDG data path.

docs.title: Listing Artifacts
docs.text:
See all artifacts currently in your local store:

skr system list

docs.title: Inspecting Artifacts
docs.text:
View detailed metadata (manifest, config, annotations) for an artifact:

skr system inspect <tag-or-digest>

docs.title: Removing Artifacts
docs.text:
To remove a specific tag (and its reference) from the local store:

skr system rm <tag>

You can remove multiple tags at once:

skr system rm tag1:v1 tag2:v1

docs.title: Pruning (Garbage Collection)
docs.text:
Removing a tag with rm does not immediately delete the underlying content blobs (layers), just the reference. To free up space by removing unreferenced blobs:

skr system prune

docs.title: Using GitHub Packages with skr
docs.text: skr supports any OCI-compliant registry, including GitHub Packages (GHCR).

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
To push or pull skills from GitHub Packages, you need a Personal Access Token (PAT).

  1. Go to GitHub Settings -> Developer Settings -> Personal access tokens -> Tokens (classic).
  2. Generate a new token.
  3. Select the write:packages scope (for pushing) and read:packages (for pulling).
  4. Copy the token.

docs.title: Login
docs.text:
Use skr to log in to ghcr.io:

skr registry login ghcr.io --username <your-github-username>
# Paste your PAT when prompted for password

docs.title: Pushing a Skill
docs.text:
1. Build your skill with the full registry tag:
skr build ./my-skill --tag ghcr.io/<your-username>/my-skill:v1
  1. Push it:
skr push ghcr.io/<your-username>/my-skill:v1

docs.title: Pulling a Skill
docs.text:
To install a skill from GitHub Packages:

skr install ghcr.io/<your-username>/my-skill:v1

Or just pull it to your local store:

skr pull ghcr.io/<your-username>/my-skill:v1

docs.title: skr
docs.text: Root command.

docs.title: skr build [path] --tag <tag>
docs.text: Build an Agent Skill artifact from a directory. - path: Path to skill directory (default: .) - --tag, -t: Name and optional tag (e.g., my-skill:v1).

docs.title: skr install <ref>
docs.text: Install a skill into the current project. - ref: Tag or digest of the skill (e.g., ghcr.io/user/skill:v1).

docs.title: skr list
docs.text: List skills installed in the current project or available globally.

docs.title: skr rm <name>
docs.text: Remove a skill from the current project configuration.

docs.title: skr sync
docs.text: Synchronize the local.agent/skills directory with the .skr.yaml configuration.

docs.title: skr publish [path] --tag <tag>
docs.text: Build a skill from a directory and immediately push it to a registry. - path: Path to skill directory (default: .) - --tag, -t: Registry reference (e.g., ghcr.io/user/skill:v1).

docs.title: skr batch publish [path]
docs.text: Publish multiple skills from a monorepo structure. - path: Root directory containing skills (default: .) - --registry: Registry host (required). - --namespace: Registry namespace (required). - --base: Git reference for change detection (optional, e.g., origin/main).

docs.title: skr registry
docs.text: Manage registry interactions.

docs.title: skr registry login <server>
docs.text: Log in to a registry. - server: Registry address (default: ghcr.io). - --username, -u: Registry username. - --password, -p: Registry password/token. - --password-stdin: Read password from stdin.

docs.title: skr registry logout <server>
docs.text: Log out from a registry.

docs.title: skr push <ref>
docs.text: Push an artifact to a remote registry.

docs.title: skr pull <ref>
docs.text: Pull an artifact from a remote registry to the local store.

docs.title: skr system
docs.text: Manage the local system store.

docs.title: skr system list
docs.text: List all artifacts (tags) in the local store.

docs.title: skr system inspect <ref>
docs.text: View metadata for a specific artifact.

docs.title: skr system rm <ref>...
docs.text: Remove one or more artifact references (tags) from the local store.

docs.title: skr system prune
docs.text: Delete unreferenced blobs (garbage collection) to free space.

docs.title: Agent Skills Specification
docs.text: This document outlines the directory structure and file requirements for an Agent Skill, compatible with skr.

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
A valid Agent Skill directory must contain a SKILL.md file at its root.

my-skill/
├── SKILL.md          (Required)
├── references/       (Optional, for technical details)
├── scripts/          (Optional, for executable tools)
└── assets/           (Optional, for static files)

docs.title: SKILL.md
docs.text: The SKILL.md file is the entry point. It must contain YAML frontmatter.

docs.title: Frontmatter
docs.text:
---
name: "my-skill"
description: "A brief description of the skill."
---
  • name: [Required] 1-64 characters, lowercase alphanumeric and hyphens. Should match the directory name.
  • description: [Required] 1-1024 characters.

docs.title: Body
docs.text: The body of the markdown file should contain the instructions and capabilities provided by the skill.

docs.title: Getting Started with skr
docs.text: This tutorial will guide you through creating, building, and running your first Agent Skill with skr.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• git installed
  • skr installed (see README)
  • Access to a GitHub repository (options)

docs.title: 1. Create a Skill
docs.text:
Create a new directory for your skill:

mkdir my-skill
cd my-skill

Create a SKILL.md file. This is the definition of your skill.

---
name: my-skill
description: A friendly greeting skill
version: 0.1.0
---

# My Skill

This skill allows agents to say hello.

docs.title: 2. Build the Skill
docs.text:
Package your skill into an OCI artifact.

skr build . --tag my-skill:v1

You should see output indicating success: 

Successfully built artifact for skill 'my-skill'
Tagged as: my-skill:v1

docs.title: 3. Inspect the Artifact
docs.text:
Verify the artifact is in your local system store.

skr system inspect my-skill:v1

You'll see metadata including the size, digest, and creation time.

docs.title: 4. Install the Skill
docs.text:
Install the skill to your agent configuration.

skr install my-skill:v1

This updates your .skr.yaml and synchronizes the skill to .agent/skills.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Publish your skill to a registry
  • Explore system management

docs.title: Tutorial: Managing Skills in a Project
docs.text: This tutorial explains how to use skr to manage Agent Skills within a specific project repository. You will learn how to configure .skr.yaml, install skills, and keep them synchronized.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• skr installed.
  • An existing git repository or project folder (e.g., my-agent-project).

docs.title: 1. Initialize Configuration
docs.text:
Create a .skr.yaml file in the root of your project. This file declares the configuration for your agent and the list of skills it requires.

# .skr.yaml
agent:
  type: "custom" # or "google-genai", etc.

skills: []

docs.title: 2. Install a Skill
docs.text:
Use the install command to add a skill to your project. This will: 1. Fetch the skill (if not already local). 2. Update .skr.yaml. 3. Sync the skill content to .agent/skills/.

Let's install a demo skill (assuming one is available in your registry or local store, e.g., my-skill:v1).

skr install my-skill:v1

If successful, check your .skr.yaml:

agent:
  type: "custom"
skills:
  - "my-skill:v1"

And verify the skill files were "hydration" into the project:

ls -F .agent/skills/
# Output: my-skill/

docs.title: 3. Synchronizing Skills
docs.text:
If you manually edit .skr.yaml (e.g., to add a list of skills from another project), or if you clone this repo on a fresh machine, you need to sync the .agent/skills directory to match the config.

Run:

skr sync

This ensures that .agent/skills contains exactly what is listed in .skr.yaml.

docs.title: 4. Version Control Guidelines
docs.text:
When using skr in a team or CI/CD environment, following these .gitignore best practices is recommended:

  • Commit: .skr.yaml (This is your source of truth).
  • Ignore: .agent/skills/ (These are generated artifacts, similar to node_modules).

Add to your .gitignore:

.agent/skills/

This way, other developers simply clone the repo and run skr sync to get all necessary skills.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: You have set up a project where Agent Skills are managed declaratively via .skr.yaml. This provides a reproducible environment for your agents.

docs.title: Tutorial: Automating Skill Updates in a Monorepo
docs.text: This guide explains how to manage a repository containing multiple skills (a "monorepo") and automate their deployment using the official skr GitHub Action.

docs.title: Repository Structure
docs.text:
We recommend a simple directory structure where each skill resides in its own folder under skills/:

my-skills-repo/
├── .github/
│   └── workflows/
│       └── release.yaml
├── skills/
│   ├── git/
│   │   └── SKILL.md
│   ├── docker/
│   │   └── SKILL.md
│   └── text-utils/
│       └── SKILL.md
└── README.md

docs.title: Automation Strategy
docs.text: To efficiently manage updates, we use skr batch publish. This command: 1. Detects changes: Checks which skills/* directories have changed since the last commit. 2. Builds: Creates OCI artifacts for modified skills. 3. Pushes: Uploads them to the registry.

docs.title: GitHub Action Workflow
docs.text: We provide a Docker-based GitHub Action that simplifies this process significantly. You don't need to write complex scripts or matrix strategies.

docs.title: .github/workflows/deploy-skills.yaml
docs.text:
name: Deploy Skills

on:
  push:
    branches: [ "main" ]
    paths:
      - 'skills/**'

env:
  REGISTRY: ghcr.io
  NAMESPACE: ${{ github.repository_owner }}

jobs:
  publish:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: read
      packages: write

    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      with:
        fetch-depth: 0 # Required for change detection

    - name: Publish Skills
      uses: andrewhowdencom/skr@main
      with:
        registry: ${{ env.REGISTRY }}
        username: ${{ github.actor }}
        password: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
        namespace: ${{ env.NAMESPACE }}
        repository: ${{ github.event.repository.name }} # Creates: ghcr.io/owner/repo.skill
        base: ${{ github.event.before }}
        path: ./skills

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Change Detection: The action (via skr batch publish) compares the current commit against base (the previous commit github.event.before) to find modified skills.
  2. Build & Push: It automatically builds and pushes artifacts for changed skills to the registry.

docs.title: Manual Publishing
docs.text:
You can also run this locally using the CLI:

skr batch publish ./skills \
  --registry ghcr.io \
  --namespace myuser \
  --base origin/main
